newsitem.title: LATVIA: LIEPAJA METALURGS TO GET INVESTMENT, EYES BOURSE.
newsitem.headline: LIEPAJA METALURGS TO GET INVESTMENT, EYES BOURSE.

text.p: Liepajas Metalurgs, the only metal producer in Latvia, said on Tuesday that its majority owner Agrosin has decided to invest $5.5 million in upgrading its rolling-mill and it is considering a bourse listing.
"The reconstruction has to be completed by August, September," managing director of the plant, Valerii Terentjev, told Reuters.
"We will thus be able to produce finer grade rolled metal sheets, for which there is more demand," he demanded.
Metalurgs is also considering a listing on the stock exchange but it has not decided which list, the official list or the secondary list.
"The intention is there but the final decision on when and which list will be taken by the shareholders general meeting," Terentjev added.
The meeting is to take place at the end of April but a date has not yet been set.

The contoling stake of Liepaja was bought by the Russian, Belorussian, Singapore joint venture late last year and according to privatisation regulations it had to invest some $5.5 million during the next three years.
Agrosin owns 72 percent of Liepajas and it employs 2,400 workers. The company says it exports 95 percent of its output.
Liepajas produced 290,000 tonnes of rolled steel last year and plans to produce 445,000 tonnes of rolled steel in 1997.
"We feel much more secure with the new investor, having solved the problems of financing and scrap metal deliveries, which is our main raw material," he added.
The company's main export market is South East Asia, North Africa and the U.S..
